awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Hominin diversity, paleobiology, and behavior at the terminal Pliocene
awd_abstract_narration:
The period of time between 2.5 to 3.0 million years ago (Ma) has long been considered one of the most critical in hominin evolution. At 3.0 Ma, multiple species of Australopithecus are represented in the fossil record across eastern and southern Africa. By 2.5 Ma, Australopithecus mostly died out, and in its place evolved two separate lineages with very different adaptations to the environment. One lineage is our own, Homo, characterized by a pattern of increased brain size and dependence on material culture that has persisted over the last several million years. The other lineage, Paranthropus, lasted over 1 million years, and was represented by three species with unique dental and facial adaptations for potentially eating tough or hard foods. Despite the obvious importance of this interval, it is poorly represented in the fossil record and few fossil specimens have been found that can shed light on the causes and patterns of the origins of these lineages. The Ledi-Geraru Research Project works in a fossiliferous region that includes this important time interval and aims to illuminate the issues relevant to the extinction of Australopithecus and the emergence of Homo and Paranthropus. The investigators will use the results of this work in public science outreach about the hominin lineage, including the critical relationship between environmental variance and hominin adaptations. The project also will foster international collaborations and student training. 
 
In the last decade, the investigators have identified fossiliferous sediments in the Afar region of Ethiopia that range from 2.9 to 2.4 Ma before present. Finds from these sediments include a 2.8 million year old mandible that is the earliest known representative of the genus Homo, and additional fossils suggesting that there were multiple hominin species existing at roughly the same time in the region. In addition, several localities in the Ledi-Geraru Research Project area show evidence that hominins were using stone tools to gain access to animal tissues and resources. Continued paleoanthropological research will be conducted at Ledi-Geraru Project sites to recover additional fossil and archaeological materials and better understand relationships between hominin behaviors and environmental contexts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Ledi-Geraru Research Project (LGRP) team works in the Lower Awash Valley in the Afar Region, Ethiopia. The major paleontological goals of this project were to 1) extend paleontological and geological surveys to focus on, and identify more of, the critical interval after the last known appearance of Australopithecus afarensis (2.95 Ma) but prior to the appearance of the genus Homo (2.8 Ma), 2) increase the sampling of the hominin (early Homo) and non-hominin paleontological record at the 2.8 Ma horizon in the study area to address hypotheses of climate change and hominin evolution, and 3) reconstruct past habitats and depositional environments at varying spatial and temporal scales, and create and link "paleoscapes" using faunal and geological indicators. The paleontology team concentrated on refining the context of the several hominin specimens previously recovered in the Gurumaha and Lee Adoyta sedimentary packages, as well as adding to the faunal collections of the two Golden Sands regions (Lee Adoyta and Asboli). Despite a curtailed 2020 season due to COVID and a delay until 2024 for additional fieldwork, the team accomplished this in conjunction with higher resolution stratigraphy and 3D imaging by the geology team. We have determined that there are at least two hominin species deposited within a kilometer of one another, which implies major paleoenvironmental change from Australopithecus afarensis times (ending at 2.95 Ma in the region) to 2.8 Ma. We also recovered several hominin teeth from slightly younger deposits (2.67Ma) in the Lee Adoyta Basin, which do not belong to the genus Homo. We were finally able to return to the National Museum of Ethiopia in 2022 and began working on preparing and analyzing the new faunal specimens collected in 2018 and 2020. We are currently preparing hominin and faunal specimens collected in 2024. We have identified some species previously unknown from this area, with ecological signals of patchy wooded and wetland environments. We are now focusing on whether or not the different hominin species are associated with different mammalian communities using various analytical techniques. The team is presenting several of our results at international conferences in 2024, and is currently preparing publications describing the hominin and faunal diversity discovered at Ledi-Geraru over time.

 Intellectual Merit

Our work has uncovered different hominin species existing together during a critical time period in human evolution. We have also provided important data on the environments and the mammalian communities in which these hominins existed.

 Broader Impacts

We have included field-based experiential training for three graduate students, two women and one man, for the duration of this portion of our collaborative grant. Two of these students are Ethiopian scholars who learned field techniques in paleontology and geology, and will continue to work with our project. The work has contributed substantially to the dissertations and/or professional development of these students. Our field operations provided meaningful economic support and respect to the rural communities near the study area and our Afar collaborators are co-authors on our research products. The team has presented on the results of our work at national and international conferences and will continue to share our results.
